verses.text: Afterward, Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.
verses.comment: This marks a pivotal shift in Job's attitude; previously he refrained from blaming God, now intense personal lament begins. The idea of cursing one's birthday is echoed in Jeremiah 20:14.

verses.text: Job spoke and said:
verses.comment: This introductory formula highlights the solemn nature of what Job is about to say.

verses.text: "Let the day perish on which I was born, and the night that said, 'A man is conceived.'"
verses.comment: Job wishes his birth had never occurred, emphasizing deep despair. The phrase 'a man is conceived' refers to his very beginning, showing an existential depth to his suffering.

verses.text: "Let that day be darkness! May God above not seek it, nor light shine upon it."
verses.comment: The language here points towards divine judgment or abandonment, reiterating the seriousness of Job’s sense of loss.

verses.text: "Let darkness and shadow of death claim it; let a cloud settle upon it; let blackness of the day terrify it."
verses.comment: ‘Shadow of death’ is a phrase used elsewhere to describe the deepest suffering (cf. Job 10:21). Here, Job frames his birthday as deserving total oblivion.

verses.text: "As for that night, let thick darkness seize it! Let it not rejoice among the days of the year; let it not come into the number of the months."
verses.comment: Job desires erasure from all remembrance—an image that resonates with the concept of loss of blessing and existence.

verses.text: "Look, let that night be barren; let no joyful shout come into it."
verses.comment: Job wishes his conception night had been fruitless, emphasizing his deep sorrow.

verses.text: "Let those curse it who curse the day, those skilled to rouse Leviathan."
verses.comment: ‘Leviathan’ is a mythical sea monster symbolizing chaos (cf. Job 41:1). Job references sorcerers who would try to curse a day, showing ancient views of supernatural power.

verses.text: "Let the stars of its dawn be dark; let it hope for light, but have none; nor see the eyelids of the morning."
verses.comment: Dawn is a metaphor for hope, so Job denies his birthday any hope or blessing.

verses.text: "Because it did not shut the doors of my mother's womb, nor hide trouble from my eyes."
verses.comment: Job recognizes his birth as the means through which he experiences suffering.

verses.text: "Why did I not die from the womb? Why did I not perish when I came out of the belly?"
verses.comment: Job questions the purpose of his existence; it echoes the broader human condition and ancient questions about suffering and divine providence.

verses.text: "Why did knees receive me, or breasts give me milk?"
verses.comment: The nurturing described hints at the gift and sanctity of life, even amid suffering, raising the value of every human person.

verses.text: "For then I would have lain down and been quiet; I would have slept; then I would have been at rest,"
verses.comment: Death is envisioned as a place of peace, a motif reoccurring in wisdom literature. Early Christian theology explores how rest in death refers to hope of a future resurrection.

verses.text: "with kings and counselors of the earth, who built ruins for themselves,"
verses.comment: Job sees death as a great equalizer—kings and commoners alike enter the same fate, emphasizing the fleeting nature of earthly achievement.

verses.text: "or with princes who had gold, who filled their houses with silver."
verses.comment: Earthly wealth is rendered meaningless in death, connecting with New Testament themes on detachment from riches (cf. Luke 12:20).

verses.text: "Or why was I not hidden like a miscarriage, like infants who never saw the light?"
verses.comment: Job equates non-existence with quiet. This verse evokes the mystery of life and suffering, which later Christian thought sees as prefaced in the experience of the Incarnation.

verses.text: "There the wicked cease from troubling, and there the weary are at rest."
verses.comment: Death is described as restful, foreshadowing the Christian concept of eternal rest. Christ's own words concerning rest for the weary (Matt. 11:28) fulfill this longing.

verses.text: "There the prisoners are at ease together; they do not hear the voice of the taskmaster."
verses.comment: The end of suffering for captives symbolizes liberation, a key image for redemption fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: "The small and great are there, and the servant is free from his master."
verses.comment: All are equal in death—a principle underpinning many theological perspectives on dignity and ultimate justice.

verses.text: "Why is light given to him who is in misery, and life to the bitter in soul,"
verses.comment: Rhetorical questioning points to the mystery of suffering and why God allows light and life amid pain.

verses.text: "who long for death, but it does not come, and search for it more than for hidden treasures,"
verses.comment: Job expresses the human longing for relief, even for death, highlighting the intensity of his suffering.

verses.text: "who rejoice exceedingly, and are glad when they find the grave,"
verses.comment: Despair is so intense that even the grave is seen as deliverance; this foreshadows later hope for resurrection (cf. John 11:25).

verses.text: "Why is light given to a man whose way is hidden, whom God has hedged in?"
verses.comment: Job feels trapped by God, who once protected him. The switch from blessing to restraint is a profound image of the sovereignty of God in human affairs.

verses.text: "For my sighing comes instead of my food, and my groanings pour out like water."
verses.comment: Job’s suffering is so severe it replaces his sustenance, a motif seen in lament Psalms and prophetic suffering.

verses.text: "For the thing I feared has come upon me, and what I dreaded has happened to me."
verses.comment: Job’s inner fears are now reality. Suffering and fear are universal experiences, addressed and overcome through faith and hope in the fullness of God’s plan.

verses.text: "I am not at ease, nor am I quiet; I have no rest, but trouble comes."
verses.comment: Job ends this lament with total desolation, foreshadowing the suffering servant motif (cf. Isa. 53), later fulfilled in Christ, whose own agony brings ultimate redemption for every troubled soul.
